description: squeue displays information about jobs located in the Slurm scheduling queue. It shows job and job step information including job ID, partition, name, user, state, time, nodes, and node list. The command provides extensive filtering and formatting options to customize the output for monitoring and scripting purposes.

installation.notes: Part of the Slurm workload manager. Requires access to a Slurm cluster with slurmctld running.

global_options.description: Display information about jobs and job steps in all partitions, including hidden partitions and jobs from federated clusters. By default, jobs in hidden and unavailable partitions are not displayed.
Filter output to display only jobs charged to the specified account(s)
Display one job array element per line. Without this option, the array elements are combined on a single line with the array index values displayed using a condensed expression.
Display one job array element per line (same as --array)
Display jobs from the federation if a member of one
Do not print a header on the output. This is useful for scripting when only raw data is needed.
Print a help message describing all squeue options
Do not display information about jobs in hidden partitions. This is the default behavior.
Repeatedly gather and report the requested information at the interval specified in seconds. For better responsiveness, the interval may be split into several smaller requests.
Display information about the specified job(s). Multiple job IDs can be specified as a comma-separated list. If no jobs are specified, display all jobs.
Produce JSON output. The optional parser argument specifies the JSON parser to use.
Report more of the available information for the selected jobs or job steps, subject to any constraints specified. This includes time limit, start time, and more detailed state information.
Display jobs requesting the specified license(s). Multiple license names may be comma separated.
Display only jobs from the local cluster, ignoring federated cluster jobs
Display jobs on the specified cluster(s). Multiple clusters can be specified as a comma-separated list. The keyword 'all' can be used to query all clusters.
Display only jobs belonging to the current user. Equivalent to --user=$USER.
Display jobs with the specified name(s). Multiple names may be comma separated.
Do not convert units from their original type (e.g., 2048M will not be converted to 2G)
Exclude jobs belonging to the current user from the display

Specify the output format using format codes. The format specification is of the form '%[[.]size]type[suffix]'. Size specifies the minimum field width. A '.' before size means right-justify. Type is a single character format code. Suffix is an arbitrary string to append. Common format codes: %A (Job ID), %a (Account), %C (CPUs), %D (Nodes), %e (End time), %i (Job/step ID), %j (Name), %l (Time limit), %L (Time left), %M (Time used), %N (Node list), %P (Partition), %q (QoS), %r (Reason), %S (Start time), %t (State compact), %T (State extended), %u (User), %V (Submit time).

Specify the output format using long field names. Multiple fields are comma-separated. Common field names: Account, AllocNodes, Cluster, Command, Dependency, EndTime, JobArrayID, JobID, Name, NodeList, NumCPUs, NumNodes, NumTasks, Partition, Priority, QOS, Reason, StartTime, State, StateCompact, SubmitTime, TimeLeft, TimeLimit, TimeUsed, UserID, UserName.
Display jobs in the specified partition(s). Multiple partitions may be comma separated.
For pending jobs submitted to multiple partitions, list each partition-job combination on a separate line with the associated partition-specific priority
Display jobs using the specified Quality of Service (QoS). Multiple QoS names may be comma separated.
Display jobs using the specified reservation(s). Multiple reservation names may be comma separated.
Display jobs that have been running for longer than the specified duration
Display jobs that have been running for shorter than the specified duration
Display job step information. If a list of step IDs is provided, only those steps are displayed.
Display sibling jobs on federated clusters
Sort output by the specified field(s). Multiple fields may be comma separated. Prefix with '-' for descending order. Default sort is by increasing job ID.
Display the expected start time and resources to be allocated for pending jobs. This shows information about when the scheduler expects the job to start.

Display jobs in the specified state(s). Multiple states may be comma separated. State values: PENDING (PD), RUNNING (R), SUSPENDED (S), CANCELLED (CA), COMPLETING (CG), COMPLETED (CD), CONFIGURING (CF), FAILED (F), TIMEOUT (TO), PREEMPTED (PR), BOOT_FAIL (BF), NODE_FAIL (NF), DEADLINE (DL), OUT_OF_MEMORY (OOM), RESIZING (RS), REVOKED (RV), SPECIAL_EXIT (SE), and all.
Display jobs belonging to the specified user(s). Multiple users may be comma separated. User IDs may be specified numerically.
Print a brief help message describing the available options
Report details of squeue actions. Multiple -v options will further increase verbosity.
Display version information for squeue and exit
Display jobs running on or requesting the specified node(s). A node range expression may be used.
Produce YAML output. The optional parser argument specifies the YAML parser to use.
Expand filename patterns in StdOut, StdErr, and StdIn fields
Query only job state information. This reduces overhead when only state information is needed.

output_formats.default: Tabular format showing: JOBID, PARTITION, NAME, USER, ST (state), TIME, NODES, NODELIST(REASON). Columns are space-separated with headers.
output_formats.long: Extended format (-l) showing: JOBID, PARTITION, NAME, USER, STATE, TIME, TIME_LIMIT, NODES, NODELIST(REASON). Includes full state names instead of abbreviated codes.
output_formats.custom: User-defined format via -o or -O options. Supports extensive format codes for all job attributes.
output_formats.json: JSON structured output via --json option. Suitable for programmatic parsing.
output_formats.yaml: YAML structured output via --yaml option. Human-readable structured format.
output_formats.format_codes: Format codes for -o option: %A (Job ID), %a (Account), %B (Executing host), %c (Min CPUs/node), %C (CPUs requested/allocated), %d (Min temp disk), %D (Node count), %e (End time), %E (Dependencies), %f (Features), %F (Array job ID), %g (Group), %G (Group ID), %h (Oversubscription), %H (Sockets/node), %I (Cores/socket), %i (Job/step ID), %J (Threads/core), %j (Name), %K (Array index), %k (Comment), %l (Time limit), %L (Time remaining), %m (Min memory), %M (Time used), %n (Requested nodes), %N (Allocated nodes), %O (Contiguous), %p (Priority normalized), %P (Partition), %q (QoS), %Q (Priority raw), %r (Reason), %R (Node list/Reason), %s (SLUID), %S (Start time), %t (State compact), %T (State extended), %u (User), %U (User ID), %v (Reservation), %V (Submit time), %w (Workload char key), %W (Licenses), %x (Excluded nodes), %X (Core spec count), %y (Nice), %Y (Expected nodes), %z (S:C:T), %Z (Work directory).
output_formats.job_state_codes: Compact state codes: BF (Boot Fail), CA (Cancelled), CD (Completed), CF (Configuring), CG (Completing), DL (Deadline), F (Failed), NF (Node Fail), OOM (Out of Memory), PD (Pending), PR (Preempted), R (Running), RD (Reservation Deleted Hold), RF (Requeue Fed), RH (Requeue Hold), RQ (Requeued), RS (Resizing), RV (Revoked), S (Suspended), SE (Special Exit), SI (Signaling), SO (Stage Out), ST (Stopped), TO (Timeout).

environment_variables.name: SLURM_BITSTR_LEN
environment_variables.description: Specifies the number of bytes used for the display of job array indices. Default is 64 bytes. Set to 0 to display the full expression.
environment_variables.affects_command: Controls how job array index ranges are displayed in output

environment_variables.name: SLURM_CLUSTERS
environment_variables.description: Specifies the cluster(s) to use. Equivalent to --clusters option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Sets default clusters for multi-cluster queries

environment_variables.name: SLURM_CONF
environment_variables.description: Path to the Slurm configuration file
environment_variables.affects_command: Specifies which Slurm configuration to use

environment_variables.name: SLURM_TIME_FORMAT
environment_variables.description: Specifies the time format for output. Can be 'standard', 'relative', or a strftime format string.
environment_variables.affects_command: Controls how timestamps are displayed in output

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_ACCOUNT
environment_variables.description: Default account filter. Equivalent to -A option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Filters output to specified account by default

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_ALL
environment_variables.description: If set to any value, equivalent to --all option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Displays all partitions including hidden ones

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_FORMAT
environment_variables.description: Default output format. Equivalent to -o option.

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_FORMAT2
environment_variables.description: Alternative default output format using long field names. Equivalent to -O option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Sets default output format using long names

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_PARTITION
environment_variables.description: Default partition filter. Equivalent to -p option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Filters output to specified partition by default

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_SORT
environment_variables.description: Default sort order. Equivalent to -S option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Sets default sort order for output

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_STATES
environment_variables.description: Default state filter. Equivalent to -t option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Filters output to specified states by default

environment_variables.name: SQUEUE_USERS
environment_variables.description: Default user filter. Equivalent to -u option.
environment_variables.affects_command: Filters output to specified users by default

exit_codes.meaning: Error - general error occurred (e.g., invalid options, connection failure)

common_usage_patterns.description: Display all jobs in the queue with default format
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu   train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]
 123457   compute  analyze      bob PD       0:00      1 (Resources)
 123458       gpu     test  charlie CG       0:45      2 node[005-006]

common_usage_patterns.description: Display only the current user's jobs
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu   train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]
 123459       gpu   eval     alice PD       0:00      2 (Priority)

JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu   train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]
 123460   compute    batch      dan  R    5:12:33      8 node[010-017]

common_usage_patterns.description: Display jobs in a specific partition
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu   train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]
 123458       gpu     test  charlie CG       0:45      2 node[005-006]
 123459       gpu   eval     alice PD       0:00      2 (Priority)

common_usage_patterns.description: Display jobs with custom output format
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
          123456       gpu    train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]
          123457   compute  analyze      bob PD       0:00      1 (Resources)

common_usage_patterns.description: Display long format with extended information
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
Wed Jan 15 10:30:00 2025
  JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER    STATE       TIME TIME_LIMI  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu    train    alice  RUNNING    2:30:15   8:00:00      4 node[001-004]
 123457   compute  analyze      bob  PENDING       0:00   2:00:00      1 (Resources)

common_usage_patterns.description: Display pending jobs with expected start time
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST          START_TIME  NODES SCHEDNODES           NODELIST(REASON)
 123457   compute  analyze      bob PD 2025-01-15T11:00:00      1 node008              (Resources)
 123459       gpu     eval    alice PD 2025-01-15T12:30:00      2 node[001-002]        (Priority)
[Output refreshes every 10 seconds showing current queue state]

common_usage_patterns.description: Display jobs without header for scripting

common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
123450_1       gpu  array    alice  R    0:30:15      1 node001
123450_2       gpu  array    alice  R    0:30:10      1 node002
123450_3       gpu  array    alice PD       0:00      1 (Resources)

common_usage_patterns.description: Sort jobs by state and priority
common_usage_patterns.output_example:
JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123457   compute  analyze      bob PD       0:00      1 (Resources)
 123459       gpu     eval    alice PD       0:00      2 (Priority)
 123456       gpu    train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]

JOBID PARTITION     NAME     USER ST       TIME  NODES NODELIST(REASON)
 123456       gpu    train    alice  R    2:30:15      4 node[001-004]

common_usage_patterns.description: Output in JSON format for programmatic use

error_messages.message: slurm_load_jobs error: Invalid job id specified
error_messages.meaning: The job ID provided does not exist in the system
error_messages.resolution: Verify the job ID is correct. The job may have completed and been purged from the queue. Use sacct to view historical job information.

error_messages.message: slurm_load_jobs error: Unable to contact slurm controller (connect failure)
error_messages.meaning: Cannot connect to the Slurm controller daemon (slurmctld)
error_messages.resolution: Check if slurmctld is running. Verify network connectivity to the controller. Ensure SLURM_CONF points to the correct configuration file.

error_messages.message: slurm_load_partitions error: Invalid partition name specified
error_messages.meaning: The specified partition does not exist
error_messages.resolution: Use 'sinfo' to list available partitions. Check partition name spelling.

error_messages.meaning: The specified user does not exist in the system
error_messages.resolution: Verify the username is correct. The user must exist on the cluster.

error_messages.meaning: An invalid job state was provided to the -t option
error_messages.resolution: Use valid state names: PENDING, RUNNING, SUSPENDED, COMPLETED, CANCELLED, FAILED, TIMEOUT, NODE_FAIL, PREEMPTED, BOOT_FAIL, DEADLINE, OUT_OF_MEMORY, COMPLETING, CONFIGURING, or their abbreviations.

error_messages.meaning: The format string provided to -o contains invalid format codes
error_messages.resolution: Review the format codes in the squeue man page. Ensure correct syntax: %[.]size]type

interoperability.notes: squeue queries the slurmctld daemon for current queue state. For historical job information, use sacct. For more detailed control over individual jobs, use scontrol show job. The output of squeue is commonly piped to other commands for job management workflows.

permissions.read_operations: Any user can view jobs in the queue. By default, all jobs from all users are visible unless the cluster has PrivateData configured to hide other users' jobs.
permissions.notes: The PrivateData configuration option in slurm.conf can restrict what information users can see about other users' jobs. Administrators always have full visibility.

limitations: Only displays jobs currently in the queue; completed jobs are removed after a configurable time (MinJobAge)
For historical job information, sacct must be used instead
The --start option provides estimated start times which may change as the queue state changes
Job array indices may be truncated based on SLURM_BITSTR_LEN setting
Output is a point-in-time snapshot; queue state changes continuously
Federated cluster queries may have increased latency
Some format fields may not be available depending on Slurm configuration and accounting settings

reads_from.description: squeue reads comprehensive job state information from the Slurm controller including all job attributes, resource requests, and current status
squeue reads node allocation information to display which nodes are assigned to running jobs and node reasons for pending jobs
squeue reads partition state to determine which partitions and jobs to display based on visibility settings

triggered_by.effect: New job appears in squeue output with PENDING state
Job state changes from PENDING to RUNNING, NODELIST populated with allocated nodes

triggered_by.state_change: Job completes, fails, or times out
triggered_by.effect: Job state changes to terminal state (COMPLETED, FAILED, TIMEOUT) then removed from queue
Job state changes to CANCELLED then removed from queue
Job reason changes from dependency-related to resource/priority reason
Pending jobs may transition to RUNNING state

triggered_by.state_change: Job held or released via scontrol
triggered_by.effect: Job reason changes to reflect held status or becomes eligible for scheduling

consistent_with.shared_state: Job attributes (job_id, name, user, state, nodes) for jobs that are still in queue or recently completed
Full job state including all attributes shown by squeue plus additional internal details
Partition and node state information used to explain job pending reasons
Job priority values and components for pending jobs
